Jon’s near yell of her name startled her right out of her skin. Spinning around with her hands clasped in front of her belly, Dany met to nervous features of the charming man who she already found herself coming to adore. “Yes?”

“Would you…” Fingers clenching and unclenching against the grainy wood of his bench, Jon struggled to find his bravery. This was all that he’d ever wanted since clapping eyes on her. He couldn’t screw this up. “Would you… like to go out with me some day?”

For moments she stood there, mouth slowly falling open. Blinking owlishly down at Jon, Dany’s mind took a beat to process his request before kicking start again, along with the feeling of pure glee. The smile lit up her whole being. He was asking her out! “Yes!”

“Really?” Jon asked, taken aback. Were his ears deceiving him? All he had to do was ask? It was that simple?

“Yes, Jon. I’d like that! Very much.” Teeth finding her bottom lip, she bit down hard. The slight sting of pain told her that this was real.

“Oh.” Now it was his turn to gawp. “Well…. Okay. Cool! Umm… I’ll come by and get you.”

“When?” Dany queried breathlessly. Her heart galloped a tattoo so hard she thought it would explode out of the confines of her cage of ribs. She felt as if she could just float away.

“How about, this weekend. Sunday?”

“Sure. That sounds lovely.” A giddy giggle stole pass her drawn up lips. “I can’t wait.”

“Me too.” A matching grin transformed his lips into a beaming smile. “I’ll see you again real soon, Dany.”

With a little nod, tucking a strand of hair behind her ear, Dany pushed her front door open. Turning back, she gave Jon a bashful wave before heading back inside, feeling suddenly invigorated.

Waving back at her with a goofy smile, he watched wistfully as she disappeared through the throng of kids. If he weren’t in public, Jon would have jumped up and did a happy victory jig. Instead, he resorted to sweeping his puppy up in a big hug and rocking him. It was all thanks to Ghost that his first meeting with Dany went so well. Oh, he should probably call his friend up too and give him his thanks for his sagely advice. But that can wait till later. Now, he had a date to plan.

The work day passed by in a breeze. And if Missandei noticed the spring in her friend’s step and the constant smile pushing at her cheeks, she sure didn’t say anything. She’d get the news out of Dany later. It would seem her best girl was well on her way to a new beginning.

summary: Though the timeline for Jon as Brandon's bastard don't really work out, couldn't it have been fudged a little bit by Ned - like...
question: Though the timeline for Jon as Brandon's bastard don't really work out, couldn't it have been fudged a little bit by Ned - like sure, Jon is a few months old! A bit small, but every child is different.. With Ashara's being his implied mother (who very conveniently can't deny it). I mean, why couldn't it have worked?
answer:
I’m still pretty sceptical on the timelines alone. Between the last possible date Brandon could have conceived a child (i.e. the date of his arrest in King’s Landing, unless you think Aerys was allowing conjugal visits), and the rough time Jon actually was conceived (assuming it was roughly contemporaneous with Robb’s conception):

  • Word was sent to Winterfell of Brandon’s arrest.
  • Rickard Stark travelled from Winterfell to King’s Landing.
  • The “trial” occurred.
  • Word was sent to the Vale demanding the arrests of Ned and Robert.
  • Ned travelled from the Vale to Winterfell.
    • We learn most of Ned’s route in Davos I, ADWD: starting from the Eyrie, he crossed the mountains, travelled to the Fingers, found a fishing boat willing to transport him across the Bite, then ran into a storm and got blown to the Sisters.
    • From there it’s technically speculation that he then sailed to White Harbour and travelled from there to Winterfell, but there’s no more sensible way to do things.
  • Ned raised the banners of the North.
  • Ned and his armies marched from Winterfell to Riverrun.

There would have been wait time between some of these points, too, even if it was a matter of a day or two. Fitting this sequence of events into even three months is tricky. More likely it took four+. Unless Jon is a very small four-month-old, again keeping in mind that four months is the youngest possible Jon could be with this lie, we’re starting to strain credibility.

Recall also that Ned’s nineteen or so at this point, and probably doesn’t know much about comparative infant development. And then recall that if Ned’s caught lying about Jon’s parentage even once, the likelihood that the truth outs goes up exponentially. Ned lying is exactly the sort of thing that would get the people who know him to start asking why he’d do such a thing - and ending up recalling that Ned and Howland were the sole survivors of the mission to rescue Lyanna, and Lyanna did spend a lot of time in Rhaegar’s company, and wow, this suddenly makes a lot more sense. Busted.

Then there’s the point that I didn’t mention in my first post on the topic - pretending Jon is Brandon’s bastard son accomplishes nothing vis-a-vis Catelyn seeing him as a threat. Brandon’s sons would come before Ned himself when it comes to inheriting Winterfell, and we’re back to the fact that Catelyn’s aware that bastards can be legitimised, and bastards can make the argument that they should inherit.

Short version: “Brandon’s bastard Jon” is a bad lie because it introduces unnecessary implausibility, if not outright impossibility, without actually fixing a core quality-of-life issue for Jon. It only spares Ned’s reputation.

And Ned’s character must also be accounted for here. Raising Jon is his problem now. He’s not going to spill it over to Brandon or Ashara, even posthumously.

summary: in a random burst of inspiration i wrote a little drabble about dany & sansa and jon in all his overprotective big brother...
body:
in a random burst of inspiration i wrote a little drabble about dany & sansa and jon in all his overprotective big brother glory! (you can also read it here on ao3) 

Jon has threatened every man who even dared to look at Sansa, as is his duty as her big brother. But his own aunt, the powerful Queen of the Seven Kingdoms, who just so happens to have three dragons? Jon knew it was not the best idea, but his own words, spoken so many years ago in a cold and dirty tent, were playing on a loop in his head. I’ll protect you, I promise.

So here he is, knocking on his aunt’s chamber door, always the Northern Fool. When she answers, her eyes say she knows why he’s here. As he takes a deep breath, she cuts him off before he has the chance to get even a single word in -

“Little nephew, I know. Sansa is the most important person in the world to you. She gave you a reason to live, she brougght home and family back to you, and so on and so forth. I know this, you have no idea how many times you have told me all of this. But you don’t have to worry. I will take care of my queen, Jon.” She smirked. “And besides, who has three dragons? Me, or you?”

“I-”

“Goodbye, Jon. I think I hear my lady calling my name.” Daenerys was slowly shutting the door in his face, and Jon was sure he could hear not one, but two, girlish voices giggling at him behind the door. He sighed, feeling utterly cowed by his tiny aunt.
